importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The release year of 'Diwale Dulhania Le Jayenge' (DDLJ), which became a cultural phenomenon and a defining film of early 1990s Indian cinema.
The date of the article's publication, marking the 30th anniversary of the film's release, highlighting its enduring cultural relevance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period of economic liberalization and cultural transformation in India during the 1990s, which provided the social and economic context for DDLJ's success and resonance.

keyTakeAways: DDLJ remains a beloved and culturally significant Bollywood film that continues to captivate Indian audiences decades after its release.
The film reflects the national mood of the 1990s, capturing a transitional era of globalization, identity, and cultural awakening in India.
It introduced a new narrative model in Indian cinema by centering on the cross-cultural love story of two Indians raised abroad, challenging traditional family dynamics.
The film launched the on-screen partnership of Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, which became a defining romantic template in Bollywood for years to come.
The film’s success influenced a generation of Indian films, including 'Pardes', 'Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham', and 'Kal Ho Naa Ho', which adopted similar themes and structures.
The Maratha Mandir cinema in Mumbai has maintained a daily screening of DDLJ for nearly 30 years, symbolizing its deep-rooted cultural endurance.
The film’s music, costumes, and narrative style created a lasting emotional connection with audiences, transcending generational and regional boundaries.
While the film is celebrated for its romance and emotional depth, contemporary critics note that its gender dynamics and portrayal of female agency are now viewed as dated.

namedEntities.name: Diwale Dulhania Le Jayenge
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 1995 Bollywood romantic film, commonly known as DDLJ, which tells the story of two young Indians raised in London falling in love during a trip across Europe, facing familial opposition, and ultimately overcoming obstacles to be together.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The film is central to the article, serving as a cultural touchstone that has remained relevant for over three decades, influencing Indian cinema and resonating with audiences on emotional and national levels.

namedEntities.name: Shah Rukh Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of India's most iconic Bollywood actors, who starred in DDLJ as the lead male character Raj Malhotra.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role in DDLJ marked a turning point in his career, elevating him to 'cinema royalty' and establishing a long-lasting on-screen partnership with Kajol.

namedEntities.name: Kajol
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A leading Bollywood actress who co-starred with Shah Rukh Khan in DDLJ as Simran Singh, the female lead.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her performance in DDLJ helped cement her status as a leading romantic icon in Indian cinema and solidified the Shah Rukh Khan–Kajol pairing as a cinematic standard.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is credited with introducing a new narrative model in Indian cinema by portraying love as a journey of negotiation between individual desire and family tradition.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores the enduring cultural impact of the 1995 Bollywood film 'Diwale Dulhania Le Jayenge' (DDLJ), which continues to captivate Indian audiences more than three decades after its release. It highlights the film's role as a cultural touchstone during India’s economic liberalization in the 1990s, capturing a nation in transition between tradition and globalization. Directed by Aditya Chopra and starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, the film centers on a cross-cultural romance that defies family opposition, ultimately winning over both parents and lovers. The narrative influenced a generation of Indian films, establishing a template for future romantic blockbusters. The Maratha Mandir cinema in Mumbai continues to host a daily screening of DDLJ, demonstrating its deep-rooted resonance. The film’s music, costume design, and emotional authenticity have cemented its place in Indian cinematic history. While modern critics note dated gender politics and limited female agency, the film remains a symbol of enduring romantic idealism and national cultural identity.
title: Why a Bollywood classic about forbidden love still captivates Indian movie-goers 30 years on
